snippet: Creating a no-fly zone and stepping up combat air patrols would open a direct conflict with Syria, going beyond the U.S. mission against the Islamic State.
abstract: Turkey, with United States continuing to pressure it to do more in fight against Islamic State, is hardening around idea of creating buffer zone along its frontier with Syria; American military planners are said to be looking at how to implement such a plan, which would require no-fly zone and stepped up combat patrols to take out Syrian air defense systems.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Istanbul, and Ceylan Yeginsu from London. Michael R. Gordon contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Creating a no-fly zone and stepping up combat air patrols would open a direct conflict with Syria, going beyond the U.S. mission against the Islamic State.

headline.main: Turkey Seeks Buffer Zone on the Border With Syria
headline.print_headline: Turkey Seeks Buffer Zone on the Border With Syria

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
